newsitem.title: THAILAND: Thais end probe on bank licences bribery charge.
newsitem.headline: Thais end probe on bank licences bribery charge.

text.p: A government investigator said on Monday that allegations made in August by a former Thai cabinet minister that bribes had been sought by some of his colleagues to license three new banks were unfounded.
"There was no evidence that kickback money for the new bank licenses had been sought or received," said Prasit Damrongchai, secretary-general at the Office of the Commission of Counter Corruption.

Current deputy Interior Minister Chalerm Yoobamroong, who was Justice Minister in the previous government, had alleged that bidders for the bank licences were asked to pay billions of baht in kickbacks to unnamed ministers in the then cabinet to secure the licences.
A probe was launched after Chalerm's allegations.
The Finance Ministry has plans to grant three new bank licences to three bidders who qualified in a preliminary round of bidding.
The three bidders comprise consortia led by the Italian-Thai Development Plc, General Finance and Securities Plc and MBK Property and Development Plc
Analysts said the ending of the investigation on the bank licence scandal would now pave the way for Finance Minister Amnuay Viravan to accelerate the issue of the licences to the bidders.
Amnuay has said he would try to speed up the issue of the three new bank licences by the end of January 1997.
